review.title: Using Social Networks to Aid Homeless Shelters: Dynamic Influence Maximization under Uncertainty - An Extended Version
review.abstract: This paper presents HEALER, a software agent that recommends sequential intervention plans for use by homeless shelters, who organize these interventions to raise awareness about HIV among homeless youth. HEALER's sequential plans (built using knowledge of social networks of homeless youth) choose intervention participants strategically to maximize influence spread, while reasoning about uncertainties in the network. While previous work presents influence maximizing techniques to choose intervention participants, they do not address three real-world issues: (i) they completely fail to scale up to real-world sizes; (ii) they do not handle deviations in execution of intervention plans; (iii) constructing real-world social networks is an expensive process. HEALER handles these issues via four major contributions: (i) HEALER casts this influence maximization problem as a POMDP and solves it using a novel planner which scales up to previously unsolvable real-world sizes; (ii) HEALER allows shelter officials to modify its recommendations, and updates its future plans in a deviation-tolerant manner; (iii) HEALER constructs social networks of homeless youth at low cost, using a Facebook application. Finally, (iv) we show hardness results for the problem that HEALER solves. HEALER will be deployed in the real world in early Spring 2016 and is currently undergoing testing at a homeless shelter.

sections.heading: 2. RELATED WORK
sections.text: First, we discuss work related to maximization. There are many algorithms for finding "seed sets" of nodes to maximize influence in networks [10, 14, 1, 25]. However, all of these algorithms assume no uncertainty in the network structure and select a single seed set. In contrast, we select several seed sets sequentially in our work to select intervention participants. Also, our problem takes into account uncertainty about the network structure and influence status of network nodes (i.e. whether a node is affected or not). Finally, we use a different diffusion model, as we will explain later. Golovin et. al. [8] introduced adaptive submodularity and discussed adaptive sequential selection (similar to our problem), and they proved that a greedy algorithm has a (1 − 1 / e) approximation guarantee. Unlike our work, they do not assume any uncertainty in the network structure.

sections.heading: 3. HEALER’S DESIGN
sections.text: It consists of two main components: (i) a Facebook application for collecting information on social networks; (ii) a DIME solution approach that solves the DIME problem (introduced in Section 5). We first explain the components of HEALER and then explain HEALER's design. Facebook Application: HEALER collects information on social connections in the social network of the homeless by interacting with young people via a Facebook application. We choose Facebook for collecting information as Young et. al. [31] show that approximately 80% of homeless young people are active on Facebook. Once a fixed number of homeless young people are registered in the Facebook application, HEALER analyzes the Facebook contact lists of all registered homeless young people and creates the social network between these young people. HEALER adds a connection between two people when and only if both people are friends on Facebook; and (ii) are registered in its Facebook application.

sections.heading: 6. HEAL: DIME PROBLEM SOLVER
sections.text: The theories above show that DIME is a hard problem, as it is difficult to get any reasonable approximations at all. We model DIME as POMDP [16] for two reasons. Firstly, POMDPs are a good fit for DIME, because (i) we perform several interventions sequentially, similar to sequential POMDP actions; and (ii) we have a partial observation (similar to POMDPs) due to uncertainties in the network structure and the influence of nodes. Secondly, POMDP solvers have recently shown great promise in terms of generative politics efficiently [23]. We will now explain how we do DIME on a POMDP.States. sections.heading: 7. EXPERIMENTAL RESULTS
sections.text: All our experiments are run on a 2.33 GHz 12-core Intel machine with 48 GB of RAM. All experiments are averaged over 100 runs. We use a metric of "indirect influence" in this section, which is "indirectly" influenced by the number of nodes. Thus, the total number of affected nodes could be 26 (say) and thus the indirect influence is 26 − 20 = 6. In all experiments, the propagation and existence probability values on all network margins are uniformly set to 0.1 and 0.6, based on the results in Kelly et al. [9] We loosen these parameter settings later in the section. All experiments are significant.

sections.heading: 8. CONCLUSION
sections.text: This paper focuses on the important problem of selecting participants in sequential interventions organized by homeless shelters in order to raise awareness of HIV prevention practices among homeless youths. This is an extremely important problem, since homeless youths are at high risk of HIV (approximately 10% of homeless youths are HIV positive). While previous work attempts to solve this problem, it simply fails to extend it to the actual sizes and requirements of the real world. HEALER presents the problem as POMDP and uses a completely new set of algorithms (HEAL, TASP and Evaluates) to achieve a 100-fold acceleration in moderate networks, a new software agent to solve this problem that scales up to the requirements of the real world.
